title: Deep Dive into Memory Safety and Low-Level Systems
description: This roadmap systematically explores memory management, common vulnerabilities, and safety techniques from foundational hardware concepts to advanced exploitation and modern language approaches.

nodes.title: Foundational Computing Concepts
nodes.description: Understand the basic architecture underlying all memory operations.

nodes.title: CPU-Memory Interaction
nodes.description: Learn how the CPU fetches and stores data from memory.

nodes.title: Memory Hierarchy and Caching
nodes.description: Explore registers, caches, RAM, and storage devices.

nodes.title: Virtual vs. Physical Addressing
nodes.description: Differentiate between virtual and physical memory addresses.

nodes.title: Data Representation and Endianness
nodes.description: Understand how data is stored and byte order conventions.

nodes.title: Exercise: Memory Access Simulation
nodes.description: Write a program to simulate memory access patterns and observe cache effects.

nodes.title: C/C++ Memory Fundamentals
nodes.description: Master the core memory concepts inherent in C/C++ programming.

nodes.title: Pointers and Address Arithmetic
nodes.description: Grasp the concept of pointers and their manipulation.

nodes.title: Stack vs. Heap Memory
nodes.description: Differentiate between stack-allocated and heap-allocated memory.

nodes.title: Function Calls and Stack Frames
nodes.description: Understand how functions use the stack for arguments and local variables.

nodes.title: Arrays, Strings, and Pointers
nodes.description: Explore the close relationship between arrays, strings, and pointers.

nodes.title: Exercise: Stack and Heap Allocation
nodes.description: Implement a program that explicitly uses both stack and heap memory, observing addresses.

nodes.title: Manual Memory Management
nodes.description: Learn the intricacies of explicit memory allocation and deallocation.

nodes.title: Malloc/Free and New/Delete
nodes.description: Master the C and C++ standard library functions for dynamic memory.

nodes.title: Dangling Pointers and Use-After-Free
nodes.description: Identify and prevent common errors when memory is freed prematurely.

nodes.title: Memory Leaks
nodes.description: Understand when allocated memory is no longer reachable but not freed.

nodes.title: Double-Free Vulnerabilities
nodes.description: Learn about the dangers of freeing the same memory block twice.

nodes.title: Exercise: Debug Memory Errors
nodes.description: Write C programs demonstrating dangling pointers, leaks, and double-free, then debug them.

nodes.title: Common Memory Corruption
nodes.description: Explore prevalent memory-related bugs that lead to instability and security issues.

nodes.title: Buffer Overflows/Underflows
nodes.description: Understand how writing beyond array boundaries corrupts memory.

nodes.title: Integer Overflows/Underflows
nodes.description: Learn how arithmetic operations on integers can wrap around.

nodes.title: Format String Vulnerabilities
nodes.description: Discover how incorrect format string usage can lead to memory reads/writes.

nodes.title: Uninitialized Memory Reads
nodes.description: Understand the risks of reading from memory locations not explicitly initialized.

nodes.title: Exercise: Exploit Simple Buffer Overflow
nodes.description: Craft an input to a vulnerable C program to trigger a buffer overflow.

nodes.title: Memory Safety Techniques
nodes.description: Implement strategies and tools to prevent memory-related bugs.

nodes.title: RAII and Smart Pointers
nodes.description: Utilize Resource Acquisition Is Initialization for automatic resource management.

nodes.title: Bounds Checking and Safely Sized Buffers
nodes.description: Implement checks to prevent out-of-bounds memory access.

nodes.title: Memory Sanitizers (ASan, Valgrind)
nodes.description: Learn to use dynamic analysis tools to detect memory errors.

nodes.title: Defensive Programming Practices
nodes.description: Adopt coding habits that inherently reduce memory safety risks.

nodes.title: Exercise: Integrate ASan/Valgrind
nodes.description: Use ASan or Valgrind to find and fix memory errors in existing code.

nodes.title: Advanced Memory Concepts
nodes.description: Dive deeper into how memory is managed and optimized at a system level.

nodes.title: Custom Memory Allocators
nodes.description: Understand the design and implementation of allocators like jemalloc or tcmalloc.

nodes.title: Memory-Mapped Files
nodes.description: Learn to map file contents directly into a process's address space.

nodes.title: Data Alignment and Padding
nodes.description: Explore how data structures are laid out in memory for performance.

nodes.title: Garbage Collection Principles
nodes.description: Review different garbage collection algorithms and their trade-offs.

nodes.title: Exercise: Implement a Simple Allocator
nodes.description: Write a basic custom memory allocator using sbrk or mmap.

nodes.title: OS Memory Management
nodes.description: Understand how operating systems manage and protect memory for processes.

nodes.title: Process Memory Layout
nodes.description: Examine the typical memory segments of a running process (text, data, heap, stack).

nodes.title: Memory Protection Unit (MMU)
nodes.description: Learn how hardware enforces memory access permissions and virtual memory.

nodes.title: System Calls for Memory (mmap, sbrk)
nodes.description: Explore the OS interfaces for requesting and releasing memory.

nodes.title: ASLR and DEP/NX Bit
nodes.description: Study Address Space Layout Randomization and Data Execution Prevention.

nodes.title: Exercise: Inspect Process Memory
nodes.description: Use tools like /proc/[pid]/maps or debuggers to inspect a running process's memory layout.

nodes.title: Security & Exploitation
nodes.description: Investigate how memory vulnerabilities are exploited and mitigated in real-world scenarios.

nodes.title: Stack Smashing Attacks
nodes.description: Understand how buffer overflows can overwrite return addresses.

nodes.title: Return-Oriented Programming (ROP)
nodes.description: Learn how to chain existing code snippets to achieve arbitrary execution.

nodes.title: Heap Exploitation Techniques
nodes.description: Explore methods for manipulating heap metadata to gain control.

nodes.title: Mitigation Bypass Techniques
nodes.description: Study methods to circumvent ASLR, DEP, and other security measures.

nodes.title: Exercise: Craft a ROP Chain
nodes.description: Build a simple ROP chain to execute a shellcode after a buffer overflow.

nodes.title: Modern Memory Safety
nodes.description: Examine how newer languages and paradigms address memory safety challenges.

nodes.title: Rust's Ownership and Borrowing
nodes.description: Understand Rust's compile-time memory safety guarantees.

nodes.title: Go's Concurrency and GC
nodes.description: Explore Go's approach to memory management and safe concurrency.

nodes.title: Formal Verification and Static Analysis
nodes.description: Learn about advanced techniques for proving software correctness and finding bugs.

nodes.title: Hardware-Assisted Memory Safety
nodes.description: Investigate emerging CPU features designed to enhance memory safety (e.g., ARM MTE).

nodes.title: Exercise: Implement Safe Code in Rust
nodes.description: Rewrite a C program with known memory issues into Rust, ensuring compile-time safety.
